bibl.title: Abstract: The Pfeiffer Reaction in Yellow Fever, by Hideyo Noguchi, 1924

div1.p: Noguchi's article concerns the Pfeiffer reaction as evidence of a yellow fever infection.

div1.head: Abstract: The Pfeiffer Reaction in Yellow Fever, by Hideyo Noguchi, 1924
div1.opener:
Noguchi, H.: The Pfeiffer Reaction in Yellow Fever, Am.J.Trop. M.,
4:131, 1924.
div1.p:
In most cases of 'yellow fever the author has found the
Pfeiffer reaction (lysis of the specific organism by specific
immune sera) positive in convalescence and in patients recently
recovered from the disease. Such a reaction is confirmatory
evidence of the disease. A negative Pfeiffer reaction is
occasionally obtained in patients recovering from yellow
fever in which the diagnosis was definitely established
clinically, owing to the weakness of the reaction, individual
peculiarity, or to the strain variations in the organisms used
for the test. The author reports that in one case the
reaction was prompt and decisively positive sixty-five days
after onset of the disease, and in another case four years
after a severe attack of yellow fever in a physician who had
been in an infected area two years previous to making the
test. On the other hand the test was negative in a person
who lived in an area where yellow fever was prevalent without
contracting the disease, and in a person vaccinated three
years previously. In cases of yellow fever in Brazil, the
test was positive with Leptospira icteroides strains from
Ecurador, Mexico and Peru.
